properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero in some areas on Sunday. Conditions will improve gradually at the end of the day. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:29:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T03:30:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3933599208.2019
Area: Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible tonight. Snow will continue into tonight with total snowfall amounts between 8 and 12 cm possible by Sunday morning. The significant snow in combination with increasing winds and falling temperatures tonight will result in difficult travel conditions across the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:07:03-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall changing to snow. The lingering rain will soon transition to a period of snow late this evening. Rainfall accumulations of 20 to 30 mm are expected before the transition. Note that Environment and Climate Change Canada uses a rainfall warning criteria of 25 mm or more in 24 hours or less when the ground is frozen and has a reduced ability to absorb rainfall. For the latest information concerning the potential for flooding in your area, please refer to your local Conservation Authority or the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T15:59:11-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain giving 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected overnight tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T13:59:48-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High water levels expected today. Location: South shore of Nova Scotia. Time span: During the high tide near noon today. Large waves with rough and pounding surf enhanced by storm surge can be expected along the Atlantic coast during high tide today, and may cause some minor flooding along the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:59:27-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, freezing precipitation and strong winds are expected. Locations: Churchill Falls and Churchill Valley. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h Sunday night into Monday. Time span: continuing until Monday morning. Remarks: Snow may become heavy at times Sunday morning. The snow is likely to change to ice pellets or freezing rain during the day on Sunday and possibly to rain by Sunday evening. Precipitation will transition back to snow Sunday night. Strong northwesterly winds are also expected to develop Sunday night, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-15T18:24:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T02:25:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2931901064.2019
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm grip on far Northern Ontario. Extreme cold wind chills near or below minus 45 are forecast tonight into Sunday morning. Windchills are forecast to moderate Sunday afternoon and remain above Extreme Cold Wind Chill Warning levels Sunday night. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:05:53-00:00

Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Severn, Peawanuck, Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain over New Brunswick will taper to showers this morning and then change to flurries as temperatures fall later today. Additional rainfall: 5 to 10 mm. Locations: northern New Brunswick. Time span: Until mid morning. Remarks: Rain over northern areas of New Brunswick will taper to showers this morning then change to flurries. Strong westerly winds will usher in much colder air later today and temperatures will fall to between minus 10 and minus 13 tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T13:59:52-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixture of snow, freezing precipitation and rain is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville and along the coast from Postville to Lodge Bay. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall: near 5 mm south of Groswater Bay. Lesser amounts elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until Sunday night. Remarks: Snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain on Sunday, before tapering to drizzle or freezing drizzle Sunday evening. The precipitation will be accompanied by strong easterly winds along the coast. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Clear skies overnight will result in frigid temperatures with extreme wind chill values near minus 40. Hazardous wind chills are expected to recur each night over the next few days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, followed by rain, is expected. Total snowfall: 10 cm except near 20 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: near 15 mm. Locations: Labrador Straits. Time span: continuing until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will transition through ice pellets to freezing rain Sunday morning. The highest snowfall amounts are expected inland and over higher terrain with lesser amounts along the coast. A prolonged period of freezing rain may occur over inland areas during the changeover. Precipitation is expected to change to rain over most areas around midday on Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Houston because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. For the duration of this advisory the use of woodstoves is prohibited within the Districtof Houston, unless the woodstove is the only source of heat in a dwelling. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-15T20:33:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-15T04:34:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2262324121.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Flurries at times heavy and a risk of snowsqualls are expected to develop overnight tonight and persist on Monday. Total snowfall: locally up to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Time span: overnight tonight until early Monday evening. Remarks: A strong westerly flow of cold air over the Gulf of St. Lawrence will cause flurries at times heavy to develop overnight tonight. Blowing snow over exposed areas is likely and there is a possibility of the development of snowsqualls giving heavy snow and poor visibility. These conditions will diminish late Monday and Monday night as a ridge of high pressure approaches. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T00:27:29-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: Nain, Natuashish, Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: Sunday morning until Sunday night. Remarks: Scattered flurries will develop late tonight and transition to snow, at times heavy, on Sunday morning. The snow will continue through Sunday night in the Nain and Natuashish areas, but is expected to mix with rain in the Hopedale area. Precipitation will taper off over all areas early Monday. Strengthening easterly winds will accompany the snow, resulting in poor visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will begin to ease overnight Sunday night. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds expected tonight. Maximum gusts ; 90 km/h. Location: Coastal areas of the Acadian Peninsula. Time span: Tonight and Monday. Remarks: Westerly winds gusting to 90 km/h are expected to develop early this evening and are forecast to persist on Monday. The strongest gusts will likely be at exposed areas near the coast. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T00:30:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T08:31:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3230784626.2019
Area: Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Location: Magdalen Islands Maximum wind gusts: up to 100 km/h Time span: tonight through Monday Remarks: Strong westerly winds will develop tonight with gusts reaching as high as 90 km/h by Monday morning. Strong winds will continue through the day on Monday with peak winds reaching as high as 100 km/h. Winds are currently expected to diminish late Monday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T00:30:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T08:31:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3319494737.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 millimetres are expected through Sunday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T13:59:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T03:27:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2689529632.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Further rainfall accumulations: 20 to 30 mm. Locations: the Connaigre and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: continuing until this afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-15T22:59:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T08:34:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3169194364.2019
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Torrential rain is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Further rainfall accumulations: 10 to 30 mm. Locations: the southwest coast of Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: continuing until noon today. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:59:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T08:33:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2642386319.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Additional blizzard conditions with poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will develop late in the day Sunday and will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds. These conditions will persist into Monday. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-15T19:25:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-15T03:26:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2847627032.2019
Area: Quaqtaq, Kangirsuk
